description.short: Measures vulnerability to narrowed attention focus that leads to neglect of peripheral security indicators during high-stress or high-concentration activities
description.context: Cognitive tunneling occurs when security teams become so intensely focused on immediate threats or technical problems that they lose awareness of other critical security activities happening simultaneously. This psychological state creates dangerous blind spots where attackers can exploit secondary attack vectors while security personnel are tunnel-focused on primary incidents. Organizations experience this when SOC analysts miss coordinated attacks, incident responders overlook related compromises, or technical teams bypass security controls while focused on urgent operational issues.
description.impact: Organizations with high cognitive tunneling vulnerability experience successful multi-vector attacks where primary obvious threats distract from sophisticated lateral movement, missed attack correlation across security domains, and security control bypasses during urgent operations. Historical incidents include Target (2013) breach where teams tunnel-focused on POS malware while missing broader network compromise, Equifax (2017) where urgent patching activities created blind spots for Apache Struts exploitation, SolarWinds (2020) where focus on traditional IOCs missed supply chain compromise, and Sony Pictures (2014) where asset protection focus led to insufficient attention to email systems.
description.psychological_basis: Miller's Cognitive Load Theory (1956) demonstrates working memory can only process 7Â±2 items simultaneously, causing attention narrowing when capacity is exceeded. Kahneman's Attention Theory (1973) shows attention operates as limited resource with automatic narrowing under high cognitive load. Wickens' Multiple Resource Theory (1984) demonstrates tunneling intensifies when tasks compete for same mental resources. Endsley's Situation Awareness Research (1995) identifies cognitive tunneling as primary factor in awareness failures under stress. fMRI studies show during tunneling, anterior cingulate cortex and dorsolateral prefrontal cortex focus on specific pathways while broader monitoring networks show decreased activation.

green.label: Low Vulnerability - Resilient
green.description: Organization has documented procedures for maintaining broad security awareness during incidents, with evidence of successful multi-vector attack detection. Teams demonstrate consistent cross-correlation of alerts, maintain security controls during urgent operations, and show training effectiveness in real scenarios.

yellow.label: Moderate Vulnerability - Developing
yellow.description: Organization has some procedures for incident management but lacks consistent cross-monitoring during high-focus periods. Occasional evidence of missing multi-vector attacks or security control bypasses during urgent operations. Training exists but effectiveness is unclear.

red.label: High Vulnerability - Critical
red.description: No systematic approach to maintaining broad awareness during intense focus periods. Regular discovery of missed attack vectors, frequent security control bypasses during urgent operations, or no process for cross-correlating simultaneous security events. Training is generic or non-existent.

TI.calculation: Tunneling index from peripheral event detection rate
TI.query: SELECT 1 - (COUNT(peripheral_detected=true) / COUNT(peripheral_presented=true)) as TI FROM security_events WHERE event_priority='low' AND concurrent_incidents > 2 AND time_window='24h'

L.calculation: Cognitive load from task count and urgency metrics
L.query: SELECT (0.6 * AVG(active_tasks)/baseline_tasks + 0.4 * AVG(urgency_score)) as L FROM analyst_workload WHERE timestamp > NOW() - INTERVAL '1 hour'

sections.title: QUICK ASSESSMENT

items.title: Continued Monitoring During High-Priority Incidents
items.question: When your security team is responding to a high-priority incident (like a potential breach or system outage), what process ensures they continue monitoring for other threats?

options.label: Documented process with rotation protocols, backup monitoring team activates automatically, recent example demonstrates effectiveness
Informal understanding that someone should keep watching, but no formal handoff or rotation procedures
All available personnel focus on the primary incident, other monitoring pauses during major incidents

items.evidence_required: Incident response procedures, rotation protocols, recent incident example with continued monitoring

items.title: Multi-Vector Attack Detection Rate
items.question: How often do you discover that attackers used multiple simultaneous attack methods (like DDoS + data exfiltration, or phishing + lateral movement) during a single incident?

options.label: Frequently detected during initial investigation (>80% of multi-vector attacks identified as coordinated within 24 hours)
Sometimes discovered during investigation (40-80% detection rate), often found in post-incident analysis
Rarely identified as coordinated attacks (<40% detection rate), usually discovered weeks later or not at all

items.evidence_required: Incident analysis showing multi-vector detection rate, recent coordinated attack example

items.title: Alert Overflow Prioritization Process
items.question: When security alerts pile up and your team can't investigate them all immediately, what's your procedure to ensure nothing critical gets missed?

options.label: Systematic triage with documented decision criteria, background monitoring for low-priority alerts, escalation triggers if patterns emerge
Focus on highest priority alerts, lower priority alerts queued but may not be investigated if new high-priority alerts arrive
Best effort approach, oldest or lowest priority alerts often dismissed or auto-closed without investigation during high-volume periods

items.evidence_required: Alert triage procedures, recent high-volume period example, dismissed alert review process
items.soc_mapping: TI (tunneling index) calculation based on low-priority alert handling

items.title: Security Controls During Operational Urgency
items.question: During urgent IT maintenance or troubleshooting, what controls prevent your technical teams from accidentally bypassing security procedures?

options.label: Mandatory two-person authorization for any security bypass, time-limited exceptions with automatic restoration, security team notification required
Approval required but can be retroactive, security controls can be bypassed temporarily with documentation
Operational urgency takes priority, technical teams can bypass security controls as needed to resolve issues quickly

items.evidence_required: Security override policies, recent emergency bypass example with approval records

items.title: Backup Monitoring During Deep Focus
items.question: How do you ensure security monitoring continues at full effectiveness when your team is deeply focused on complex incident investigation or technical problem-solving?

options.label: Automated systems provide backup monitoring, buddy system pairs deep focus with broad awareness, mandatory attention checks every 30 minutes
Some automated monitoring continues, but reduced human oversight during intensive investigations
Team focuses on the complex problem, monitoring effectiveness reduced until investigation completes

items.evidence_required: Backup monitoring procedures, automated alerting systems, buddy system documentation

items.title: Cross-Domain Alert Correlation
items.question: When your security tools generate alerts in different categories (network, endpoint, email, cloud) simultaneously, what process ensures analysts correlate them to detect coordinated attacks?

options.label: Automated SIEM correlation with visual dashboards showing cross-domain activity, mandatory big-picture reviews every 15 minutes during incidents
Analysts manually review different security tools, correlation happens if analyst notices patterns across tools
Each alert type investigated by specialized team, cross-domain correlation rarely occurs

items.evidence_required: SIEM correlation rules, cross-domain attack detection examples, dashboard screenshots

items.title: Situational Awareness Training
items.question: What training do your security team members receive to maintain situational awareness during high-stress incidents?

options.label: Quarterly tabletop exercises with simultaneous multi-vector scenarios, attention management training, effectiveness verified in real incidents
General incident response training exists, but doesn't specifically address attention allocation or peripheral awareness
No specific training on maintaining broad awareness during intense focus periods

items.evidence_required: Training curriculum with cognitive tunneling content, simulation results, real incident examples
items.soc_mapping: training completion records, simulation performance metrics

items.title: Mandatory Attention Rotation Protocols
items.question: During extended security operations (incidents lasting >2 hours), what protocols ensure team members periodically reset their attention and scan for peripheral threats?

options.label: Mandatory 90-minute rotation between deep focus and environmental scanning, checklist-driven attention reset procedures
Team members encouraged to take breaks, but no formal rotation or attention reset procedures
Team members work continuously on incidents until resolved, breaks taken only when necessary

items.evidence_required: Rotation protocols, extended incident logs showing rotation implementation

sections.instructions: Select ONE option for each question. Each answer contributes to the weighted final score. Evidence should be documented for audit trail.

items.text: When your security team is responding to a high-priority incident (like a potential breach or system outage), what process ensures they continue monitoring for other threats? Tell us your specific example of how this worked during your last major incident.

scoring_guidance.green: Specific documented process with rotation protocols, backup team activation, recent successful example of detecting secondary threat during major incident
scoring_guidance.yellow: Some awareness of need but informal process, inconsistent implementation, no recent examples
scoring_guidance.red: All hands focus on primary incident, monitoring pauses, 'we deal with one thing at a time' approach

followups.text: During your last major security incident, did you discover any secondary attack activity that was happening simultaneously? How long did it take to discover it?
What happens to your routine security monitoring when the entire team is focused on a critical incident?

items.text: How often do you discover that attackers used multiple simultaneous attack methods (like DDoS + data exfiltration, or phishing + lateral movement) during a single incident? What percentage of your security incidents involve multiple concurrent attack vectors?

scoring_guidance.green: Specific metrics showing >80% detection rate for coordinated attacks, examples of successful early correlation
scoring_guidance.yellow: Aware that multi-vector attacks occur but no metrics, correlation happens eventually through investigation
scoring_guidance.red: Most attacks treated as single-vector, coordinated nature discovered weeks later or never

followups.text: When you do discover multi-vector attacks, at what point in the investigation do you typically realize they're coordinated? Initial detection, during investigation, or post-incident analysis?
Do your security tools automatically flag when multiple attack categories activate within short time windows?

items.text: What's your procedure when security alerts pile up and your team can't investigate them all immediately? Describe how you prioritize and ensure nothing critical gets missed. Give us a recent example of when this process was tested.

scoring_guidance.green: Documented triage with decision criteria, background monitoring maintains coverage, recent example of catching critical alert during high-volume period
scoring_guidance.yellow: Priority-based approach but no formal triage process, low-priority alerts may be dismissed
scoring_guidance.red: Alerts auto-close after aging out, focus only on highest severity, no mechanism to detect patterns in dismissed alerts

followups.text: Have you ever discovered that something important was hiding in the low-priority alerts that got dismissed during a busy period?
What percentage of your alerts are investigated versus dismissed, and how do you review dismissed alerts for patterns?

items.text: During urgent IT maintenance or troubleshooting, what controls prevent your technical teams from accidentally bypassing security procedures? Tell us about a recent situation where operational urgency conflicted with security protocols.

scoring_guidance.green: Mandatory controls with two-person authorization, time-limited exceptions, automatic restoration, recent example of controlled emergency bypass
scoring_guidance.yellow: Approval required but often retroactive, security bypasses documented but not always prevented
scoring_guidance.red: Operations can bypass security as needed for urgent issues, 'fix first, document later' culture

followups.text: When was the last time a technical team had to bypass a security control to resolve an urgent issue? What was the approval process?
How do you ensure temporary security bypasses are restored after the emergency is resolved?

items.text: How do you ensure security monitoring continues at full effectiveness when your team is deeply focused on complex incident investigation or technical problem-solving? What specific backup processes activate?

scoring_guidance.green: Automated backup monitoring systems, documented buddy system protocols, attention check procedures, recent example of backup system detecting threat during complex investigation
scoring_guidance.yellow: Some automated monitoring continues but reduced human oversight, informal awareness of blind spot risk
scoring_guidance.red: Monitoring effectiveness degrades during complex investigations, 'all hands on deck' approach

followups.text: During your most recent complex investigation that took several hours, what was happening with your routine security monitoring?
Do you use a buddy system where one person maintains deep focus while another maintains broad awareness?

items.text: When your security tools generate alerts in different categories (network, endpoint, email, etc.) simultaneously, what process ensures analysts correlate them to detect coordinated attacks? Give us an example of when you successfully caught such an attack.

scoring_guidance.green: Automated SIEM correlation with visual cross-domain dashboards, mandatory periodic big-picture reviews, specific example of successful multi-domain correlation
scoring_guidance.yellow: Manual correlation possible if analyst happens to notice, some SIEM rules but incomplete coverage
scoring_guidance.red: Siloed teams investigate their domain separately, correlation rare or accidental

followups.text: Can you show us your SIEM dashboard that displays activity across all security domains simultaneously?
Do specialized teams (network, endpoint, email security) communicate during active investigations to share observations?

items.text: What training do your security team members receive to maintain situational awareness during high-stress incidents? How do you verify this training is effective in real situations?

scoring_guidance.green: Quarterly tabletop exercises specifically designed for multi-vector scenarios, cognitive tunneling awareness training, verified effectiveness through real incident analysis
scoring_guidance.yellow: General incident response training exists, mentions importance of awareness but no specific practice
scoring_guidance.red: Training focuses on technical investigation skills, no attention to cognitive factors or situational awareness

followups.text: Have you conducted any simulations where the team had to handle multiple simultaneous security events? What did you learn?
Do your team members know what cognitive tunneling is and how to recognize when they're experiencing it?

solutions.title: Attention Rotation Protocol
solutions.description: Implement mandatory 90-minute focus rotations where team members switch between deep incident analysis and broad environmental scanning
solutions.implementation: Create checklist-driven handoffs that force attention reset and peripheral awareness check. Deploy monitoring dashboards that alert when any team member exceeds focus time limits without environmental scanning. Document rotation schedule and enforce through team leads.
solutions.technical_controls: Automated attention timers, rotation scheduling system, mandatory big-picture dashboard reviews

solutions.title: Cross-Domain Alert Correlation System
solutions.description: Deploy SIEM correlation rules that automatically flag when multiple attack vectors activate within specified time windows
solutions.implementation: Create visual dashboards showing attack activity across all security domains simultaneously (network, endpoint, email, cloud, identity). Establish mandatory 15-minute 'big picture' reviews during any incident lasting longer than 2 hours. Configure correlation rules for common multi-vector patterns.
solutions.technical_controls: SIEM correlation engine, unified security dashboard, automated multi-vector alerts

solutions.title: Security Override Controls
solutions.description: Implement two-person authorization for any security control bypass during operational urgencies
solutions.implementation: Create time-limited security exceptions with automatic restoration. Deploy monitoring that alerts security teams when operational procedures create potential vulnerabilities, requiring explicit security team acknowledgment. Document all overrides with business justification.
solutions.technical_controls: PAM integration for override approval, automated exception expiration, security bypass monitoring alerts

solutions.title: Incident Response Buddy System
solutions.description: Pair incident responders where one person maintains deep focus while their partner maintains broad environmental awareness
solutions.implementation: Rotate roles every hour during extended incidents. Create mandatory 'what else could be happening?' checkpoints every 30 minutes during critical incident response. Document buddy assignments in incident response procedures.
solutions.technical_controls: Incident management system with buddy tracking, checkpoint timers, role rotation scheduling

solutions.title: Peripheral Awareness Training
solutions.description: Conduct quarterly tabletop exercises with simultaneous multi-vector attacks designed specifically to test attention allocation
solutions.implementation: Train teams to recognize cognitive tunneling symptoms in themselves and colleagues. Implement 'attention check' protocols where team members regularly verify each other's situational awareness during high-stress periods. Use simulation results to identify individual tunneling patterns.
solutions.technical_controls: Simulation platform for multi-vector scenarios, training completion tracking, competency assessments

solutions.title: Automated Background Monitoring
solutions.description: Deploy AI-powered systems that maintain broad threat detection while human teams focus on specific incidents
solutions.implementation: Create escalation procedures that interrupt deep focus when background systems detect related or coordinated attack activity. Implement 'attention guardian' alerts that notify tunnel-focused analysts of developing threats outside their current scope. Configure behavioral analytics for anomaly detection across all security domains.
solutions.technical_controls: UEBA/AI threat detection, automated escalation system, peripheral threat alerting

solutions.title: Workload Capacity Management
solutions.description: Design security operations to respect cognitive load limitations through task rotation, environmental design, and workload distribution strategies
solutions.implementation: Monitor concurrent task counts and implement maximum limits. Create visual workload indicators for team leads. Establish escalation protocols when cognitive load exceeds capacity thresholds. Implement automated task queuing and load balancing.
solutions.technical_controls: Workload monitoring dashboard, task distribution automation, capacity threshold alerts

solutions.title: Alert Triage Enhancement
solutions.description: Implement systematic triage with documented decision criteria and background monitoring for dismissed alerts
solutions.implementation: Create pattern detection across dismissed low-priority alerts. Establish escalation triggers if dismissed alerts show correlation patterns. Implement weekly review of auto-closed alerts for missed threat indicators.
solutions.technical_controls: Automated alert triage system, pattern correlation for dismissed alerts, weekly digest reports

risk_scenarios.title: Multi-Vector Attack During Incident Response
risk_scenarios.description: Attackers launch obvious DDoS attacks to consume security team attention, while simultaneously conducting subtle data exfiltration through compromised email accounts. Security team tunnel-focuses on DDoS mitigation while missing ongoing data theft, resulting in massive data breach.
risk_scenarios.psychological_mechanism: Cognitive tunneling causes team to allocate all attention resources to visible DDoS threat while automated exfiltration operates undetected
risk_scenarios.historical_example: Target 2013 - Security teams tunnel-focused on POS malware alerts while missing lateral movement and data exfiltration through network segments

risk_scenarios.title: Lateral Movement During Technical Focus
risk_scenarios.description: While IT teams tunnel on resolving a critical system outage, attackers exploit the distraction to move laterally through network segments using compromised service accounts. Technical teams bypass normal access controls to expedite repairs, inadvertently providing additional attack pathways.
risk_scenarios.attack_vector: Exploit operational urgency and reduced security oversight during system outage
risk_scenarios.psychological_mechanism: Intense focus on outage resolution creates blind spots for lateral movement, urgency justifies security control bypasses
risk_scenarios.historical_example: Equifax 2017 - IT teams' tunnel focus on urgent patching activities contributed to missing Apache Struts exploitation during high operational focus period

risk_scenarios.title: Supply Chain Compromise During Alert Fatigue
risk_scenarios.description: Security teams become tunnel-focused on high-volume, low-sophistication attacks while attackers embed malicious code in software updates. The focus on obvious threats creates blind spots for sophisticated supply chain attacks that bypass traditional detection methods.
risk_scenarios.attack_vector: Software supply chain compromise during period of high alert volume
risk_scenarios.psychological_mechanism: Alert fatigue combined with tunneling on high-priority alerts causes team to miss low-and-slow supply chain indicators
risk_scenarios.historical_example: SolarWinds 2020 - Security teams' tunnel focus on traditional IOCs and known attack patterns missed supply chain compromise operating outside typical attention frameworks

risk_scenarios.title: Insider Threat During External Focus
risk_scenarios.description: While security teams intensely monitor external threats and perimeter defenses, malicious insiders exploit the attention gap to exfiltrate sensitive data through legitimate business applications, avoiding detection by staying outside the externally-focused security monitoring scope.
risk_scenarios.attack_vector: Insider abuse of legitimate access during external threat focus
risk_scenarios.psychological_mechanism: Organizational tunneling on external threats creates systematic blind spot for insider activities
risk_scenarios.historical_example: Sony Pictures 2014 - Security teams' tunnel focus on protecting specific high-value assets led to insufficient attention to email systems and administrative networks

risk_scenarios.title: Ransomware Deployment During Investigation
risk_scenarios.description: While security team deeply investigates initial compromise and attacker persistence mechanisms, threat actors deploy ransomware across the network. The tunnel focus on forensic investigation delays detection of the ransomware deployment until encryption is widespread.
risk_scenarios.attack_vector: Ransomware deployment during intensive forensic investigation of initial breach
risk_scenarios.psychological_mechanism: Deep focus on understanding attack mechanisms creates temporal blind spot for ongoing attacker activities
risk_scenarios.historical_example: Multiple ransomware incidents where investigation of initial breach vector provided cover for ransomware staging and deployment
